result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.
result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Joseph M. Crom

records.addlTxt:
2:51 PM Defendant Joseph M. Crom appeared by video, in custody.  Attorney Janae F. Hochmuth appeared by video for Joseph M. Crom.  Prosecuting attorney Gabriel David Arevalo in court for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant received and waives reading of complaint.  Court advises DE of charges/max penalties.  DE qualifies for PD representation.  Atty Hochmuth explains missed court appearance due to DE not receiving notice.  Atty Hochumuth updates DE's address.   File set for pre-trial conference/return date.  State recommends a signature bond.  No objection from Atty Hochmuth.  $500.00 SIGNATURE bond set.
Pre-trial conference scheduled for October 14, 2022 at 10:00 am.
Return date scheduled for October 31, 2022 at 01:00 pm.
Return date on October 31, 2022 at 01:00 pm.
